guides.displayName: Complete AIMEE Mining Bot Guide for Stationeers

OperationalDetails.title: Section 1: Introduction & Overview
OperationalDetails.description: AIMEE (Autonomous Intelligent Mining and Exploration Entity) is a programmable mining robot that autonomously collects surface ores. Unlike manual mining or deep miners, AIMEE roams the surface finding and collecting exposed ore deposits.

children.title: What It Can Do
items: Mine surface ores - Any ore visible on or near the surface (within 2 layers deep)
Store mined ores - Internal storage slots hold collected ore
Unload to chutes - Deposits ores into Chute Inlet or Chute Bin
Be fully programmable - IC10 chip slot for custom behavior
Be repaired - Uses Duct Tape for repairs

children.title: What It Cannot Do
items: Select specific ore types to mine
Navigate reliably over significant terrain height changes

children.title: Slot Configuration
children.description: AIMEE has three types of slots: Important: The battery slot is checked first when reading ChargeRatio via logic. Access it via slot index 0.

children.title: Power Consumption (From Game Code)
children.description: AIMEE's power draw is calculated per game tick: Practical Power Usage:
items: Moving at full speed: ~30-50W (depends on terrain)

children.title: Battery Recommendations
children.description: Tip: Use a Large Battery Cell for extended autonomous operation. AIMEE can be programmed to return for charging when battery drops below a threshold. ---

OperationalDetails.title: Section 3: Modes
OperationalDetails.description: AIMEE operates in distinct modes controlled via the <color=#88FF88>Mode</color> logic variable.

cells: Autonomously searches for and mines ore
Deposits ores into nearby Chute Inlet/Bin
READ ONLY - Indicates storage is full

children.title: Mode Details
children.description: Mode 0 (Idle): Mode 1 (Follow): Mode 2 (MoveToTarget): Mode 3 (Roam): Mode 4 (Unload): Mode 5 (PathToTarget): Mode 6 (StorageFull): ---
items: Power consumption drops to base 5W + chip
Use to pause operations or during setup
Good for guiding AIMEE to new locations
No mining occurs in this mode
Can get stuck on obstacles or height differences
Mines any ore found within 2 layers of surface
Roams randomly when no ore nearby
Attempts to deposit ores into nearby Chute Inlet or Chute Bin
Must be within 3 meters of a valid input
Returns to Mode 0 (Idle) when empty or no valid input
Better at navigating around obstacles than Mode 2
Still struggles with major terrain height changes
READ ONLY - automatically set when storage is full
Program should detect this and initiate unload sequence

cells: Count of ores within search radius

children.title: Slot Variables
children.description:
Access battery status via slot 0:

---

children.title: Compatible Devices
children.description: AIMEE can unload into any device implementing <color=#88FF88>IRobotInput</color>:

children.title: Unload Requirements
steps: AIMEE must be within 3 meters of the input device
The input slot must be empty (can accept item)
The device must allow input (`AllowInput = true`)

children.title: Unload Process
steps: Transfers one item at a time from storage to input
If no valid input found, immediately returns to Mode 0

children.title: Chute Setup Example
children.description:
Place the Chute Inlet facing AIMEE's parking/unload location. Connect chutes to your ore sorting or storage system.

---

children.title: Key Programming Patterns
children.description: Check if at destination: Wait for mode change: Read battery from slot: ---

children.title: The Y-Coordinate Problem
children.description: AIMEE struggles when the target Y coordinate doesn't match terrain height: Symptoms: Cause: MoveToTarget and PathToTarget try to reach the exact Y coordinate. If terrain is higher or lower, AIMEE can't physically reach it. Solutions:
items: AIMEE lifts front or rear wheels, "dancing"
steps: Use waypoints at known good elevations
Set TargetY slightly above expected terrain
Use Follow mode to manually guide over difficult terrain
Place unload stations on flat ground

cells: Ores must be surface or near-surface

children.title: Initial Deployment
steps: Place and build AIMEE on relatively flat ground
Set Mode to 3 (Roam) for basic autonomous mining
Place Chute Inlet within 3m of intended unload spot

children.title: Automated Setup
steps: Set up charging station (APC with battery near unload point)
Test unload sequence - verify AIMEE can reach and deposit
Monitor first few cycles for stuck conditions

children.title: Critical Logic Variables
children.description: --- Data extracted from decompiled game files: RobotMining.cs, RobotMode.cs. Values are authoritative as of game version current to January 2026.

guides.displayName: Complete LARRE Robotic Arm Guide for Stationeers

OperationalDetails.title: Section 1: Introduction & Overview
OperationalDetails.description: LARRE is a robotic arm system that travels on rail tracks to automate tasks like plant harvesting, item transport, and collection. Unlike AIMEE which roams freely, LARRE follows a fixed rail network you design.

cells: Stopping points where arm can act

children.title: Key Concept
children.description: The LARRE arm travels between junctions on the rail network. You set the TargetJunctionIndex (Setting) to tell it where to go. When it arrives at a junction, it can extend down to perform actions on devices/items below. ---

children.title: Junction Numbering
items: The starting dock determines which junction is 0
You can change the starting dock via the dock's interface (Button3)
Junction numbering wraps for looped networks

children.title: Looped vs Non-Looped Networks
children.description: Non-Looped (Linear): Looped (Circular):
items: Arm can travel in either direction

children.title: Building Tips
steps: Place rails on a ceiling or overhead structure
Junctions should be positioned over devices/plants
Bypass points allow the arm to dock and undock

OperationalDetails.title: Section 3: Hydroponics Dock
OperationalDetails.description: The Hydroponics LARRE automates plant care: harvesting, planting, and fertilizing.

cells: Not over a plant / Off / No power
Plant has issues (dehydrated, bad gas, can't heal)

children.title: Behavior (From AnimateDownFinished)
children.description: When hand is empty: When hand has item:
items: If harvestable plant exists: Harvest it (seeds if seeding, fruit if mature)
If plant is dead/stuck: Destroy and clear it
If fertilizer present but no plant: Destroy fertilizer
Can also take items from ChuteExportBin
Seed/Plant in hand + empty tray: Plants it
Fertilizer in hand + tray with plant: Fertilizes
Harvestable plant + stackable in hand: Harvest if compatible
Can also deposit items to ChuteBin

children.title: Logic Variables (Per Slot, Slot 255 = Proxy Target)

cells: 1 if seeding with seeds, 0 otherwise, -1 if no plant
Prefab hash of what will be harvested

OperationalDetails.title: Section 4: Cargo Dock
OperationalDetails.description: The Cargo LARRE moves items to and from device slots (lockers, containers, etc.).

children.title: Target Slot Index
items: Set via buttons on dock or via logic (TargetSlotIndex)
Determines which slot of the target device to interact with

children.title: Behavior (From DoContextualAction)
children.description: When hand is empty: When hand has item:
items: Takes item from target device's slot (CurrentSlotIndex)
If target slot empty and accepts item type: Deposits item
If target slot occupied and swappable: Swaps items

children.title: Slot Access Rules (From CanAccessSlot)
children.description: Cannot access slots that are:

OperationalDetails.title: Section 5: Collector Dock
OperationalDetails.description: The Collector LARRE collects items from the world or ejects items from its storage.

children.title: Behavior (From DoContextualArmAction)
children.description: Mode = Inward (Collecting): Mode = Outward (Ejecting):
items: Attracts nearby items with force (300-600N based on distance)
Collection range: 1 meter from arm tip
If over ChuteExportBin: Takes items from export bin
If over ChuteBin/ChuteInlet: Deposits to chute

cells: 1 if stationary and arm up, 0 otherwise
0 to close (dock at bypass), 1 to open (undock)
Check power connection and OnOff state
Clear path, check for blocking objects
Set correct dock as starting dock

children.title: Initial Setup
steps: Plan layout - Determine where devices/trays will be
Place rails - Connect junctions with straight/corner rails
Place dock - This is the arm itself

children.title: Hydroponics Setup
steps: Place ChuteBin or ChuteExportBin at deposit junction
Program IC or use manual control
Give arm seeds to plant (or harvest existing)

children.title: Key Commands
children.description: --- Data extracted from decompiled game files: RoboticArmDock.cs, RoboticArmDockHydroponics.cs, RoboticArmDockCargo.cs, RoboticArmDockCollector.cs. Values are authoritative as of game version current to January 2026.

guides.displayName: Complete Stirling Engine Guide for Stationeers

OperationalDetails.title: Section 1: Introduction & Overview
OperationalDetails.description: The Stirling Engine is a heat-differential power generator. It converts temperature differences between a hot gas input and the cold room atmosphere into electrical power. Unlike solar panels or solid fuel generators, it requires continuous heat input but can run indefinitely with the right setup.

children.title: How It Works
children.description:
The Stirling Engine uses the temperature difference between:

The greater the temperature difference, the more power generated. A sealed gas canister provides the working fluid that transfers energy between the hot and cold chambers.
steps: Hot Side: Connected to input pipe (receives hot gas)

children.title: What You Need
steps: Gas Canister - Any gas canister (closed, not broken)
Hot Input Pipe - Connected to hot gas source (furnace exhaust, hot atmosphere)
Output Pipe - Returns cooled gas to the loop
Cold Room - The engine's cold side needs exposure to atmosphere

children.title: Placement Requirements
items: Must be placed on a frame (verified in CanConstruct)
Cold side (fan area) must be exposed to room atmosphere
Cannot be fully enclosed - needs atmospheric access

children.title: Connection Requirements (From IsAbleToOperate)
children.description: Error State: If any requirement is not met, the engine enters Error state and outputs 0W.

cells: Valid pipe connection to hot side

children.title: Gas Canister Rules
children.description: Tip: Pre-pressurize your canister with a gas that has high thermal efficiency (like Nitrogen) for better performance. ---
items: When turned on, the canister's gas is moved into the internal atmosphere
When turned off, the gas is returned to the canister

OperationalDetails.title: Section 3: Efficiency System
OperationalDetails.description: The Stirling Engine's output is calculated by multiplying three efficiency factors:

children.title: Power Calculation Formula (From OnAtmosphericTick)
children.description: Where:

children.title: Efficiency Factor 1: Working Gas Efficiency
children.description: Different gases have different thermal efficiencies. The gas in your canister determines this factor. Note: Thermal efficiency is a property of the gas mixture. Pure gases work best.

children.title: Efficiency Factor 2: Environment Efficiency
children.description: The default curve returns 1.0 (100%) for all temperatures from 0K to 3000K, meaning room temperature typically doesn't penalize efficiency. Cold rooms = Better cooling = More power

children.title: Efficiency Factor 3: Pressure Differential Efficiency
children.description: This is the most important factor to optimize: To maximize this: ---
items: Calculated as: (Hot Side Pressure - Cold Side Pressure) / 3000
steps: Increase hot side pressure (hot gas = higher pressure)
Keep cold side as cool as possible (colder = lower pressure)

children.title: Multi-Engine Configuration
children.description: Multiple engines can share the same hot gas loop: Note: Each engine extracts heat from the gas, so downstream engines receive progressively cooler gas. ---

cells: Total moles (internal + hot side + cold side)

children.title: Note on Pressure Differential
children.description:
The <color=#88FF88>MachinePressureDifferentialEfficiency</color> is calculated internally but not directly readable via logic. However, you can estimate it if you know your hot/cold side conditions:

---

children.title: Overpressure Danger (From HandlePressureCheck)
children.description: The Stirling Engine can explode if internal pressure exceeds its MaxPressureDelta rating:

children.title: Explosion Conditions
steps: Random roll based on pressure difference
Engine takes 200 brute damage per explosion event

children.title: Warning Signs
children.description: In the tooltip display:
items: Pressure text turns red when above 80% of MaxPressureDelta

children.title: Prevention
steps: Use pressure relief systems if needed

cells: Check canister, input pipe, output pipe
Verify hot gas is actually hot

children.title: Gas Loss
children.description: When the engine is turned OFF, internal gas returns to the canister. When turned ON, canister gas moves to internal atmosphere. If canister is missing/broken when turning off, gas vents to room atmosphere. ---

children.title: Initial Setup
steps: [ ] Connect input pipe to hot gas source
[ ] Connect output pipe (for gas return loop)
[ ] Ensure cold side exposed to room atmosphere

children.title: Verification
steps: [ ] Hot side temperature significantly higher than cold side
[ ] Internal pressure not approaching danger levels

children.title: Optimization
steps: [ ] Adjust hot gas temperature/pressure for maximum output

children.title: Safety
children.description: --- Data extracted from decompiled game file: StirlingEngine.cs. Values are authoritative as of game version current to January 2026.
items: Keep room ventilated for cold side

OperationalDetails.title: The Three Furnace Types
OperationalDetails.description: Arc Furnace Furnace (Standard) Advanced Furnace
items: Best for: Iron, Gold, Copper, Silicon, Nickel, Cobalt, Lead ingots
Use when: You need lots of basic ingots and have power to spare
Combustion-based, requires fuel gas (H2 + O2 from ice)
This is what most players build first
Makes: Steel, Solder, Electrum, Invar, Constantan
Use when: You need alloys for construction and electronics
Higher pressure tolerance (max 60 MPa before explosion)
Makes: Stellite, Inconel, Hastelloy, Astroloy, Waspaloy
Use when: Building rockets or endgame equipment

OperationalDetails.title: Key Concept
OperationalDetails.description: The furnace combines whatever's inside when temperature and pressure conditions are met. YOU must load the correct ratios before igniting. Ratios must be exact - 3:1 means exactly 3:1, not approximately.

OperationalDetails.title: Safety Warning
OperationalDetails.description: All furnaces radiate heat into surrounding atmosphere. Your base WILL heat up. Plan for ventilation or isolate your smelting area.

OperationalDetails.title: Recipe (Verified)
OperationalDetails.description: Conditions:
items: Temperature: 900 K - 100 kK (wide range, easy to hit)
Pressure: 1 - 100 MPa (wide range, easy to hit)

OperationalDetails.title: What You Need
items: Iron and Coal in exact 3:1 ratio
2 Volatiles Ice + 1 Oxite Ice (provides H2 fuel + O2 oxidizer)

OperationalDetails.title: The Process
steps: Load ores FIRST - Iron and Coal in 3:1 ratio (e.g., 75 Iron + 25 Coal)
Wait - furnace will reach ~1050K and ~6.2 MPa
When "Output: Steel" shows and temp/pressure stabilize, open and collect

OperationalDetails.title: Why It Works
items: Volatiles ice releases H2 (hydrogen) - the fuel
Oxite ice releases O2 (oxygen) - the oxidizer
Combustion creates heat AND pressure simultaneously
Steel's wide acceptable ranges (900K+, 1 MPa+) make it forgiving

cells: Check the activation port, use welder or igniter

OperationalDetails.title: Solder
OperationalDetails.description: For electronics, circuits, cables Warning: Temperature has a MAX of 550K. Too hot = failure. This is the only alloy where you might need to COOL the furnace or use less ice.

OperationalDetails.title: Electrum
OperationalDetails.description: For advanced electronics, some sensors Warning: Pressure has a narrow window (0.8-2.4 MPa). Too much ice will overshoot. Use minimal ice - 1 Volatiles + 1 Oxite or less.

OperationalDetails.title: Invar
OperationalDetails.description: For precision instruments, advanced frames Warning: BOTH windows are narrow. Temperature must be 1.2-1.5 kK AND pressure must be 18-20 MPa. This is one of the hardest basic alloys. You need significant ice but precise amounts.

OperationalDetails.title: Constantan
OperationalDetails.description: For heating elements, thermocouples Notes: High minimum pressure (20 MPa) but wide ranges otherwise. Easier than Invar once you get enough pressure.

OperationalDetails.title: Critical Rules for ALL Super-Alloys
steps: Use Advanced Furnace only (60 MPa max capacity)
Recipes use ingots AND ores - some require Steel Ingots, not ores
Monitor pressure/temp constantly - windows can be very narrow
As of 2021, recipes return only 1 ingot per batch

OperationalDetails.title: Stellite
OperationalDetails.description: High-wear applications, cutting tools Notes: Most forgiving super-alloy. Wide temperature range. Good first attempt.

OperationalDetails.title: Inconel
OperationalDetails.description: Heat shields, rocket components Warning: That 0.5 MPa pressure window is brutal. Requires precise pressure control. Monitor closely and vent small amounts to dial in.

OperationalDetails.title: Hastelloy
OperationalDetails.description: Corrosion-resistant components Warning: Temperature window is only 50K (950-1000K). Pressure window is reasonable at 5 MPa range.

OperationalDetails.title: Astroloy
OperationalDetails.description: Aerospace, high-stress applications Notes: Requires Steel Ingots (smelt steel first). 10 MPa pressure window is workable. Wide temp range.

OperationalDetails.title: Waspaloy
OperationalDetails.description: Ultimate high-temp applications Notes: Highest pressure requirement (50+ MPa) but widest pressure window. Temperature is counterintuitively LOW - don't overheat!

OperationalDetails.title: Explosion Prevention
OperationalDetails.description: Prevention Rules:
items: Never overload ice - 3 Volatiles + 2 Oxite is usually the safe max

OperationalDetails.title: Heat Management
OperationalDetails.description: Furnaces radiate heat into surrounding atmosphere. A 1000K furnace WILL cook your base and kill you. Solutions:
steps: Isolate it - Put furnace in separate room with airlock, vent to space after each smelt
Vacuum smelting - No atmosphere = no heat transfer to base
Active cooling - Wall coolers + radiators if you want it indoors
Distance - Further from living space = more time to react

cells: No fuel gas or no O2
Check ice loaded, try more Oxite
Got base ingots instead of alloy
Check BOTH min AND max values
Alloy won't form despite correct values
Some alloys have narrow windows - check maximums

OperationalDetails.title: Emergency Procedures
OperationalDetails.description: Overheating base: Pressure climbing dangerously:
items: Seal furnace room from living area
Open furnace to vent (loses heat too)
Or use attached pipe to bleed off gas gradually

OperationalDetails.title: Key Notes
OperationalDetails.description: Data verified from Stationeers Wiki (January 2025). Game updates may change values - if a recipe fails, check the in-game Stationpedia (F1).
items: Check BOTH min AND max - Many alloys fail from exceeding maximums
Super-alloys return 1 ingot per batch (as of 2021 update)
Inconel and Astroloy need Steel Ingots - smelt steel first

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Tolerance (From Lungs.cs)
OperationalDetails.description: Calculation: <color=#88FF88>ZeroDegrees (273.15K) ± offset</color>

OperationalDetails.title: Ideal Human Atmosphere
OperationalDetails.description: Safe Ranges:
items: Pressure: 50-200 kPa total (too high = suit warning)

OperationalDetails.title: Atmospheric Requirements (From LungsZrilian.cs)
OperationalDetails.description: Critical: Volatiles (H2) are NOT toxic to Zrilians - they breathe it! But Volatiles ARE toxic to Humans.

cells: Uses same threshold as human O2

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Tolerance (From LungsZrilian.cs)
OperationalDetails.description: Zrilians have wider temperature tolerance than Humans:

OperationalDetails.title: Ideal Zrilian Atmosphere
OperationalDetails.description: Safe Ranges:

OperationalDetails.title: Zrilian Danger Signs
OperationalDetails.description: *The UI still shows the O2 icon, but Zrilians need Volatiles, not Oxygen.

OperationalDetails.title: Atmospheric Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Robots have no breathing requirements:

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Tolerance
OperationalDetails.description: Robots have wider temperature tolerance than organic species, but still take damage from extreme temperatures. Exact limits depend on specific robot type.

OperationalDetails.title: Power Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Instead of food/water, robots need:
items: Some robots can recharge from power networks

OperationalDetails.title: Starvation & Dehydration Damage
OperationalDetails.description: When Nutrition or Hydration reaches 0:
items: Healing occurs when fed/hydrated if damage < certain threshold

OperationalDetails.title: Food Sources
OperationalDetails.description: Both species can eat the same foods:

OperationalDetails.title: The Human-Zrilian Problem
OperationalDetails.description: Humans need: O2 (breathe) + no Volatiles (toxic) Zrilians need: Volatiles (breathe) + no Pollutant (toxic) These requirements are mutually exclusive:
items: Volatiles are life support for Zrilians
They cannot share the same air

OperationalDetails.title: Solutions for Multi-Species Bases
items: Everyone wears suits with appropriate tanks

OperationalDetails.title: Suit Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Human Suits: Zrilian Suits:

OperationalDetails.title: Human First Minutes
steps: Find/build shelter before suit runs out
Set up O2 supply (Oxite ice → furnace/electrolyzer)
Remove Volatiles from atmosphere (vent or filter)

OperationalDetails.title: Zrilian First Minutes
steps: Find/build shelter before suit runs out
Set up Volatiles supply (Volatiles ice → furnace/electrolyzer)

OperationalDetails.title: Gas Sources
OperationalDetails.description: Data extracted from decompiled game files: Lungs.cs, LungsZrilian.cs, Entity.cs, SpeciesClass.cs, Chemistry.cs. Values are authoritative as of game version current to January 2026.
